Perhaps the first step would be to check how successfully we can automatically convert the current user guide from LaTeX to Markdown.

time","id":"111-1","$type":"PeriodIssueCustomField"}],"attachments":[],"idReadable":"CPPT-6","summary":"Transform CppT user guide into an online guide","updated":1565269780148,"project":{"shortName":"CPPT","$type":"Project"},"resolved":null,"tags":[],"reporter":{"login":"am963","$type":"User"},"wikifiedDescription":"

The CppTransport guide is a very comprehensive introduction to the CppTransport framework and serves as a very good resource for obtaining results using CppT. However, the user guide is an over 130 page document with a theoretical physics introduction, installation instructions, code snippets and many configuration options all in one. The size of this document can be fairly daunting to new users or somewhat computer-illiterate users who's expertise may not lie in coding & unix usage, and so put off potential users of our framework.

This could be easily transformed into an online user-guide that (at least in my experiences) are much more user-friendly, clearer, easier to navigate & search in than one monolithic pdf document. If we are interested in making CppTransport more user friendly, then this would be a task that wouldn't take too long to complete, and would, in my opinion, aid beginner user's experiences significantly.

Since there exists many platforms that allow for easy source code documentation (see below for examples) that we could easily use these ourselves for free hosting, where the only time required would be to write the new online documentation.

ReadTheDocs: https://readthedocs.org/ example: https://camb.readthedocs.io/en/latest/
GitBooks: https://docs.gitbook.com/ example: http://opendata.atlas.cern/books/current/openatlasdatatools/_book/create-a-new-plot.html

time","id":"111-1","$type":"PeriodIssueCustomField"}],"attachments":[],"idReadable":"CPPT-28","summary":"Refactor worker integration payloads to include detailed timing information per-triangle","updated":1565085940627,"project":{"shortName":"CPPT","$type":"Project"},"resolved":null,"tags":[],"reporter":{"login":"ds283","$type":"User"},"wikifiedDescription":"

Currently, when each work assignment is complete, workers report the total integration time and the number of integrated items. This is sufficient to predict time-to-completion if we are assuming each integration item takes a uniform time, but if we are modelling the integration time then more information is needed.

The workers need to be refactored to track integration time per work item and return this to the master node in the final payload. The same information must be reported to the worker scheduler where it can be used to update the current regression model, and (eventually) the current time-to-integration estimate.

Since fixing CPPT-21 the autobuilder is broken, because there is no Travis environment that provides a version of Bison more up-to-date than 3.0.4. This is available on Bionic, whereas what we need is Disco.
